ovdesc.p: Encompassed within the Funds Transfer Module is a fully operational Standing Order Application. This Application provides the following facilities:
1. Funds Management Initiated By Balance Levels

The User can determine, on any account, Funds Management conditions by specifying balance levels which can operate in two ways: As an indicator identifying a balance level starting from which funds must be transferred either into, or out of, the Account
2. Fixed and Preset Payments

This will allow the User to load Standing Orders as Fixed payments with known amount and frequency (e.g. the monthly payment of the rent) or as preset payments where the amount is unknown (e.g. payment of gas bill).
3. Diary Instructions
Any account Diary instructions can be defined with their related frequency. An on-line retrieval facility (Sto.Diary) will then allow the User to check at any time the outstanding Diary instructions.
4. Direct Debits

This facility will allow the User to load the Direct Debit mandates which the bank has received from the Customer and which authorises the bank to accept Direct Debits received on the Account. When the Direct Debits are actually received by the bank, the User will then access this file to check if the appropriate mandate has been received from the Customer.
5. Maturing Deposits

This facility will allow the User to pay away the balance on an account to the beneficiary details set up on the standing order on a particular date specified on the record. The facility can be used to mature a fixed term deposit account.
6. Periodic Payment of Interest
This facility will allow the User to pay away any interest capitalised on an account periodically to the beneficiary details specified on the record.
If required, up to 999 different Standing Order instructions can be created on any account.

During the End Of Day processing, the Application will access the internal file (Standing.Order.Fqu) to process all Standing Orders due for each day since the last run date up to and including todays date. Two separate end of day processes are run, STO.BALANCES is run at end of day to process Balance Maintenance Standing Orders, STO.PAYMENTS is run at start of day to process all other Standing Orders. The following steps will then be taken by the Application:

(i) A Funds Transfer transaction will be generated for all Standing Orders due since the last run date and these transactions will be automatically Authorised provided no error conditions or overrides exist.

(ii) Where error conditions or overrides exist (e.g. there are insufficient funds on the Standing Order account to execute the instruction), the Funds Transfer Transaction will be put on a Held status (code IHLD) and this transaction will be listed on the Exception Display of the Funds Transfer Application. The next day, the User can then access these transactions, make the necessary corrections and/or determine the action to be taken on overrides. These transactions will then follow the normal validation and authorisation process of the Funds Transfer Application.

(iii) When the Application is processing BI Balance Maintenance Standing Orders and funds are not available to pay into the Account, an unauthorised Funds Transfer transaction will be generated with a status of IHLD. The override field will specify the Amount Required, the Amount available and, if applicable, the Minimum balance to be kept in the Account from which the funds have to be taken. With the help of this information, the User will then decide on what action to take.

(iv) Any transaction generated by the Standing Order Application can be identified from the content of the internal field Inward Payment Type which will contain the value of STO and the Standing Order sequential number.

All of the files detailed within the chart have the standard 3 versions: .'Live' file .'Unauthorised' file .'History' file.

Identifies a Supplementary Balance to be Transferred TO when a BI Standing Order transaction is generated by the System.
Example:
Let us suppose that a Customer requests to cover any overdrawn balance in his current account by a transfer from his savings account. If the current account balance is overdrawn by 150.00 and:
1. Field 11 is left blank

In this case, an amount corresponding to exactly the overdraft will be transferred into the current account, i.e. 150.00. This will mean that the next debit on this current account will overdraw it again and trigger a new BI transaction.
2. Field 11 has an Amount input

In this case, not only the overdraft amount will be transferred but also the amount specified in this field. If 200.00 has been input in this field, the total amount transferred will be equal to 350.00 i.e. 150.00 (overdraft amount) + 200.00. The new balance of the current account will be CR 200.00 and is not bound to become overdrawn with the next debit activity.

The debit account (if a customer acct) must correspond to currency market of FTCREDIT. b) If FTDEBIT is set up and not FTCREDIT, then as (a) except that accounts must correspond to FTDEBIT. c) If both FTCREDIT and FTDEBIT are set up the credit account must correspond to FTCREDIT and the debit account to FTDEBIT currency markets. d) If neither FTCREDIT or FTDEBIT are set up then validation is as per default FT movement. e) The currency market input must be the same as the currency market of the account.

Identifies the type of Standing Order.

The User will first need to define the various types of Standing Orders in the Standing Order Type table which will be used to provide the enrichment of the Standing Order type being defined. When creating the Standing Order Type table, care must be taken to define exactly the 8 different types in the same format as described above. These types have been hardcoded in the Standing Order program and any other code will be refused by the Application.
The following types will be accepted:
Balance Maintenance Standing Order Types

BI The Account is to be maintained at a minimum balance and will make Payments In when the balance of this account is below the specified balance. The abbreviation BI stands for Balance maintenance In and the sequential number will be between 900 and 999.

BO The account is to be maintained at a maximum balance and will make Payments Out when the balance of this account is in excess of the specified balance. The abbreviation BO stands for Balance maintenance Out the sequential number will be between 900 and 999.
BP The balance on a fixed length savings account is to be paid away on maturity date.
Regular Payments Standing Order Types
FI The Customer has given instruction to the bank to pay on a regular basis a Fixed amount and debit one of his accounts.

PP The Customer has authorised the bank to pay bills from third parties upon presentation of these bills. The amount will vary and there is no definitive frequency. Therefore, whenever an amount is input, the payment will be made that day and the payments program will delete the amount from the Standing Order record.
PPI The interest capitalising on a savings account is to be paid away on a periodic basis.

RC Set up to indicate a payment due on a revolving credit account. Payments are made on a regular basis and the amount due can be determined using a locally developed routine. The purpose of the RC standing order is to record the amount due using the Past Due module (PD). No actual accounting entries will be produced by RC type standing orders. The RC type standing order is only applicable to systems with the PD module installed and with revolving credit accounts set up. The key should be in the 900 to 999 range.
3. Diary Standing Order Type

DIARY Used to define any type of Diary instructions on a specific account. When this Standing Order type is used, input will then become mandatory in the Field Diary Details of the Standing Order record.

This type of Standing Order instruction will be created by the User for any type of Memo instructions which are to be recorded in the System and will then provide an on-line reminder of the action to be taken when the User displays the contents of the file STO.DIARY. Specific instructions received in advance are another example of details which could be loaded as a Diary Standing Order type.

Each time that the User is creating a DIARY Standing Order item, the System will automatically update an internal file STO.DIARY which will allow Users to review, whenever desired, their own list of Diary instructions or the complete list of Diary instructions outstanding in the Application. Any diary item will remain in that list until a positive action has been taken by the User to eliminate the entry from the file. This will be done by the Standard Reverse function (code R) which, for this particular file, will not need to go through the Authorisation process.
Direct Debit Standing Order Type

DD The bank has a direct debit mandate from the Customer which authorises the bank to accept direct debits received on the Account. This type of Standing Order will be completely passive in the sense that its sole purpose is to provide the User with an on-line retrieval facility of Direct Debit mandates held by the bank. When direct debits are received by the bank, the User can then verify on-line if proper authority has been received from the Customer.
Operating Lease Standing Order Type
OL type Standing Orders cater for Operating Leasing contracts and the accrual of the Standing Order amount.
Examples:
The following are typical examples of the above Standing Order types.

1. Type BI -The customer has requested the bank to cover automatically any overdraft in his current account by debiting, for example, his savings account. In this case, the specified balance will be 0 and when the balance will be below 0 an automatic transfer will then be generated from the savings account to feed the current account.

2. Type BO - The customer has requested the bank to transfer automatically from his current account any amount in excess of a specified balance by crediting for example, his savings account. In the case the specified balance would be GBP 1,000.00 and when the balance is in excess of this amount, an automatic transfer will then be generated by the Application by which the excess of GBP 1,000.00 will be transferred out of the current account to the savings account specified by the Customer.

3. Type FI -The customer has requested the bank to pay every month, for example, the rent for his house. In this example, the amount will be specified by the Customer and in that sense the amount of the Standing Order is Fixed. To project cash flows, forward entries raised for the Internal/Customer accounts given in the Standing Order with STO.TYPE as "FI".
Under this Type, it is possible to define Credit

4. Type PP - The customer has requested the bank to pay, whenever received, the bills received from the Telephone company or the Electricity board, the Gas board etc. In this case, the amount will not be specified by the Customer but only the name of the companies for which bills may be accepted and paid automatically on their receipt by the bank. For this type of Standing Order (which is also called domiciliation on the Continent), the Customer will also have informed the relevant companies to send their bills directly to his bank.

5. Type DD -The customer has authorised the bank to accept direct debits remitted by the Building Company to pay the monthly instalments of the Mortgage loan that the Customer has contracted with the Building company. The amount is not always specified for Direct Debits Standing Order and, if entered, will only be considered as an information field.

6. Type OL - The customer may lease an asset from the bank in which case the Standing Order id is a valid customer acount and accrual entries are a debit to the suspense account and a credit to th P+L category. On repayment the customer account (from the ID) is debited with the SO amount and the suspense account ( the counterparty account no) is credited with the SO amount . The bank may lease an asset from a customer in which case the id must be a valid suspense account and the counterpary account is a valid customer account. Accrual enteries are a debit to the P+L category with the accrual amount and a credit to the suspense account. On repayment there is a debit of the standing order amount to the suspense account and a credit to the customer account

7. Type RC - A customer has a revolving credit account with payments due on a monthly basis, the amount due can vary depending on the balance of the RC account. An RC standing order is set up on a monthly frequency making use of the CUR.AMT.ROUTINE field to call a locally developed routine to calculate the amount due. When the standing order is activated the amount will be determined and used to populate the CUR.AMOUNT.BAL field. A PD.PAYMENT.DUE record will be created with a contingent balance to indicate the amount due. When a credit entry is posted to the revolving credit account with the THEIR.REFERENCE field on the STMT.ENTRY set to the RC account number, the PD record will be credited with the amount on the entry , before the amount is credited to the RC account. When the PD has been cleared it will be written to history.

For the Standing Order types BI, BO and BP, the Currency code specified in this field must be the same as the Currency of the Standing Order account.

For the Pay Method AC, the Currency code specified in this field must be the same as the Currency of the Account defined in the Beneficiary Account Number field or the currency of the account of the standing order.
In all the circumstances where the Currency of the Standing Order may differ from the Currency of the Standing Order account, an override will be required.
For the Pay Method OB and OC, the Currency code specified in this Field must be equal to the Local Currency code.

For the Pay Method OT and OD, if the Currency Code specified in this field is equal to the local currency code, the Funds Transfer record generated will be placed on hold because for these payment types a Credit Account number is mandatory for local currency.

This field is used to specify whether the corresponding commission amount entered is due to the sending bank or the receiving bank. If the standing order pay method is OT and the system has been set to produce SWIFT message MT103 - Single Customer Credit Transfer
Sender - the corresponding charge amount entered is due to the sending bank.
Receiver – the corresponding charge amount entered is due to the receiving bank.
Permitted values are Sender or Receiver, for pay method of OT with a message type of MT103 the default is Sender.
If the standing order pay method is set to OT and the system is set to produce message type MT103 there must at least one senders commission or charge present.
Identifies the Current Frequency of the Standing Order for the currency and amount specified in the previous fields.

The Standing Order Application will execute the Standing Order instruction (i.e. the currency and amount specified in the two previous fields) according to the frequency specified in this field up to and including the current end date specified in the next field.

This field is sub-divided into two elements: 1. Date 1-9 type D (date format in range 1950-2049) characters. 2. Frequency 1-5 type SS (uppercase alpha or numeric, first character alpha) characters. (Mandatory input for the Standing Order types BI, BO, FI, OL, BP PPI and DIARY. Optional for type DD. Not allowed for type PP. No default.)
Any input made in this field for the Standing Order type DD will only be for information purposes.
The date input or generated will correspond to the first execution of the Standing Order.

The first date calculated by the System (if not input under 1. above) will be the date resulting from the frequency applied to the Processing Date. If a date was input first, the frequency will then be applied on this date and not on the Processing date.
'DAILY' frequency is not allowed for Standing Order types B1, BO and BP. (BSNSS, every working day, is allowed).
An override will be required if the date input is a non-working day and the frequency is 'BSNSS'.
